awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Optimization of a Novel Compliant Mechanisms-Based Laparoscope Cleaning Device
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is a novel product for ensuring proper visualization through intraoperative scopes during laparoscopic procedures. Worldwide, 13 million laparoscopic surgeries are performed each year. Surgeons require proper visualization of the operating site which entails continually wiping the lens, reinserting the scope, relocating the surgical site, and then resuming the surgery. This difficulty in visualization results in the need to temporarily halt the operation and potentially lose critical focus of the surgical area in order to restore the surgical field of view. Surgeons repeat this process an average of six times per hour, accounting for nearly 1/3 of the operating time. This time delay results in an estimated loss of 336,000 hours of operating room procedure time and $1.25 billion in productivity losses in the United States alone each year.

This SBIR Phase 1 project will develop operating prototypes of a novel, flexible, micro-mechanical mechanism with multiple degrees of freedom. The device integrates flexible and conforming mechanisms with a wiping blade to enable real time wiping of surgical scopes and ports. This technology enables surgeons to quickly and intraoperatively re-enable laparoscope vision within the patient. The technical challenges of the project include the development of a computational engineering model that optimizes user control of off-axis stiffness, force response, and stress.  The team will also need to ensure the solution has sufficient fatigue life and predictable mechanical response throughout the duration of the procedure. Computational engineering models will be used to design and develop several manufacturable prototypes, which will be tested and validated with several currently available laparoscopes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
PROJECT OVERVIEW

Bloom Surgical is developing a single-use laparoscope cleaning attachment to eliminate in-abdominal vision disruptions and scope removal events during minimally invasive laparoscopic surgery. These recurring optical disturbances, caused by fog, bodily fluids, and debris, are a major source of frustration and are correlated with surgical complications and delays. Current practice often requires the surgeon to pause the procedure to remove and clean the scope. Through the SBIR Phase I research grant, the Bloom Surgical team has successfully proven the feasibility of a miniature lens-cleaning mechanism for laparoscopic procedures.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The work done during the Phase I grant focused on the design, development, modeling, and feasibility testing of the miniature wiper compliant mechanism. Compliant mechanisms, a unique subset of mechanical design which bend and flex to achieve their functionality, are relatively new, particularly to the field of medical devices, and provide many advantages regarding miniaturization and obtaining large motions. Analysis of these mechanisms is not trivial and traditional mechanical analysis techniques are insufficient. The team developed new models for analyzing the novel compliant mechanism design. We accomplished this through three main objectives: 

 

  1. Developing a model to predict the downward force of the wiper onto the lens and verified data with computer simulations and physical prototypes.

  2. Developing a model to predict the force with which the wiper can push material off the lens and verified data with computer simulations and physical prototypes.

  3. Developing a manufacturing method for the unique components at the scale required.

 

The first two objectives focus on ensuring the feasibility of achieving a clean lens wipe, while the third ensures that the device can be produced at the required size and in an economically viable manner.

 

The project has led to several significant technical achievements:

  1. Innovative Design and Materials: The wiper mechanism developed during the project uses nitinol's advanced properties to conform and deploy from a laparoscope distal attachment and clean the laparoscope lens during surgery while inside the abdomen.

  2. Enhanced Instrumentation Functionality: The mechanism has demonstrated improved effectiveness in maintaining a clear visual field, which is crucial for the precision and success of laparoscopic surgeries. This advancement supports better surgical outcomes and reduces the likelihood of complications.

 

 

BROADER IMPACTS

 

The broader impacts of this project extend beyond the immediate technical achievements, offering various societal and healthcare benefits:

  1. Improved Patient Safety & Outcomes: By enabling clear, uninterrupted in-abdomen visualization, the technology can reduce surgical complications and patient blood loss.

  2. Improved Procedure Efficiency & Workflow: The innovation can help optimize operating room downtime and delays, increasing procedure throughput.

  3. Enhanced Focus & Comfort of Surgical Environment: The technology has the potential to reduce surgeon decision fatigue and increase control.

Other areas of impact include

  1. Economic Growth: The project has generated economic benefits by supporting jobs and creating opportunities for business growth and further investment in healthcare technology.

  2. Educational and Research Inspiration: The project serves as a case study and inspiration for future innovations in medical device design and compliant mechanisms, providing valuable educational opportunities for students and professionals and fostering further research and development in these fields.

CONCLUSION

The advances achieved during the SBIR Phase I work have successfully overcome complex technical hurdles in developing a commercially viable design for an in-abdomen wiper mechanism. These outcomes are essential for enabling the Bloom Surgical team to develop a device that maintains uninterrupted visualization during laparoscopic surgery, improves patient outcomes, and reduces stress in the operating room. By pushing the boundaries of innovation, Bloom Surgical is paving the way for future mechanisms within and beyond the medical device field. By addressing key challenges in laparoscopic surgery and demonstrating the potential of compliant mechanisms and advanced materials, the project has contributed to improved patient care, cost savings, and broader access to advanced surgical techniques.


Last Modified: 09/01/2024
Modified by: Jacob L Sheffield
